snippet: Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to throw out charges in an inquiry into ties to a French prostitution ring, arguing that the authorities are trying to “criminalize lust.”
abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, former  head of International Monetary Fund, is seeking to settle criminal inquiry into his ties to a prostitution ring in France with legal argument that authorities are unfairly trying to 'criminalize lust'; case against Strauss-Kahn offers view into clandestine practice in certain powerful circles of French society, where secret soirees often end with naked guests and public sex with multiple partners.

byline.original: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and MAÏA de la BAUME

lead_paragraph: Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to throw out charges in an inquiry into ties to a French prostitution ring, arguing that the authorities are trying to “criminalize lust.”

headline.seo: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Says Lust Is Not a Crime
headline.main: Sex Life Was ‘Out of Step,’ Strauss-Kahn Says, but Not Illegal
headline.print_headline: Strauss-Kahn Says Sex Parties Went Too Far, but Lust Is No Crime
